lines.content: This is a project template for a greenfield Java project. It's named after the Java mascot _Duke_. Given below are
instructions on how to use it.
Prerequisites: JDK 11, update Intellij to the most recent version.
1. Open Intellij (if you are not in the welcome screen, click `File` > `Close Project` to close the existing project
1. Open the project into Intellij as follows:
1. Select the project directory, and click `OK`.
1. If there are any further prompts, accept the defaults.
1. Configure the project to use **JDK 11** (not other versions) as explained
In the same dialog, set the **Project language level** field to the `SDK default` option.
3. After that, locate the `src/main/java/duke.Duke.java` file, right-click it, and choose `Run duke.Duke.main()` (if the
code editor is showing compile errors, try restarting the IDE). If the setup is correct, you should see something
like the below as the output:
implementation group: 'org.openjfx', name: 'javafx-base', version: javaFxVersion, classifier: 'win'
implementation group: 'org.openjfx', name: 'javafx-base', version: javaFxVersion, classifier: 'mac'
implementation group: 'org.openjfx', name: 'javafx-base', version: javaFxVersion, classifier: 'linux'
implementation group: 'org.openjfx', name: 'javafx-controls', version: javaFxVersion, classifier: 'win'
implementation group: 'org.openjfx', name: 'javafx-controls', version: javaFxVersion, classifier: 'mac'
implementation group: 'org.openjfx', name: 'javafx-controls', version: javaFxVersion, classifier: 'linux'
implementation group: 'org.openjfx', name: 'javafx-fxml', version: javaFxVersion, classifier: 'win'
implementation group: 'org.openjfx', name: 'javafx-fxml', version: javaFxVersion, classifier: 'mac'
implementation group: 'org.openjfx', name: 'javafx-fxml', version: javaFxVersion, classifier: 'linux'
implementation group: 'org.openjfx', name: 'javafx-graphics', version: javaFxVersion, classifier: 'win'
implementation group: 'org.openjfx', name: 'javafx-graphics', version: javaFxVersion, classifier: 'mac'
implementation group: 'org.openjfx', name: 'javafx-graphics', version: javaFxVersion, classifier: 'linux'
The Duke Chat-Bot is an interactive task tracker. It supports
create, read, update and delete functionalities. Your tasks
are automatically saved by Duke and loaded up in future uses
The tasks you are able to add can be basic with just a task
name, or tagged with some deadline or occurrence date.
Tasks are also mark-able to indicate if they have been completed
You can list all your tasks, as well as filter them based on
The Duke Clients handler is a fully-GUI component. In this GUI,
we can add new clients and view them in a simple list. This has
only the basic feature of creating and listing all clients.
Adds a ToDo task item to the task list. A ToDo task item is
the most basic task type, containing only a task name, and
- `todo feed the pets in my room`
If successful, the to do item itself will be sent by Duke.
Otherwise, the error will be shown.
Adds an Event task item to the task list. An Event task item
is the same as a ToDo task item, but has some date associated
with it. The date indicates the occurrence of the Event item.
> ðŸ’¡ **Tip**: The timestamp is will be set to `00:00`  by
> default if no timestamp was supplied.
If successful, the event item itself will be sent by Duke.
Otherwise, the error will be shown.
Adds a Deadline task item to the task list. A deadline task item
is the same as a ToDo task item, but has some date associated
with it. The date indicates the deadline for the Deadline item.
> ðŸ’¡ **Tip**: The timestamp is will be set to `00:00`  by
> default if no timestamp was supplied.
If successful, the deadline item itself will be sent by Duke.
Otherwise, the error will be shown.
Lists out all the tasks the user has added in a simple, readable and
user-friendly format. If you include the optional date, only tasks with
a date, and whose date matches the supplied input will be shown.
If successful, the all items will be formatted and sent by Duke.
Otherwise, the error will be shown.
### `find` - Show Tasks filtered by search query
Filters all the tasks the user has created by their task name against
the given search query by the user, then lists them in a similar format
to the `list` command. Partial matches will be shown as well.
If successful, the all items will be formatted and sent by Duke.
Otherwise, the error will be shown.
Allows the user to set a task as done, for their own reference.
If successful, the marked item will be formatted and sent by Duke.
Otherwise, the error will be shown.
Allows the user to set a task as undone, for their own reference.
If successful, the unmarked item will be formatted and sent by Duke.
Otherwise, the error will be shown.
Removes the task from the user's list of tasks completely.
If successful, the unmarked item will be formatted and sent by Duke.
Otherwise, the error will be shown.
Task has been deleted: [T][X] buy groceries
Clicking on the `Add` button will cause a pop-up to appear. This pop-up will
allow users to add a first name, last name, contact and gender of the client.
However, only the first name is a mandatory field.
Once the user has added the client successfully, they will be shown in a simple
list of client values in the middle of the page.
* Duke is a chat-bot program that is capable of logging tasks which are (optionally)
* Duke automatically saves the tasks of each session upon successful termination
* of the session, and restores these tasks on the next launch.
* Creates a new Duke chat-bot instance.
System.out.println("Failed to restore saved tasks: " + e.getMessage());
return "Hello, I am Red from Among Us.\n\nWe are currently facing a crisis onboard -- there seems to be an "
+ "imposter among us...\n\nMy job is to handle chat requests, so although I might get murdered any "
+ "moment now...\n\n... How can I help you?";

* @throws DukeException If the given input is invalid.
public DukeResponse getResponse(String input) throws DukeException {
Command cmd = Command.parse(input, tasks, clients, tasksStorage);
* Adds a client to its list of clients.
* @param clientData A map of the client's key-value data pairs.

* Constructs a DukeException with the respective error message.
* @param errorMessage The message error that was encountered.

private String phoneNumber; // TODO: to new class
* Creates a new Client object. Only a Client's firstName is required, so it is the only field required in the
* @param firstName The first name of the client.
assert !firstName.isBlank() : "A client's first name should not be blank.";
* Command is the abstract base class for all possible commands that Duke recognizes.
* Command handles the parsing of user input by determining the command type given
* and then validating the supplied arguments, if any.
* Command will then return one of the executable subclass objects based on the
* All concrete implementations of Command should be able to execute based on the
* arguments supplied during the instantiation of the subclass object in Command::parse.
* They should be responsible for their entire expected behaviour within the execute method.
* Enums for all possible valid commands that are allowed to be supplied by the user.
FIND, LIST, TODO, DEADLINE, EVENT, MARK, UNMARK, DELETE, BYE,
private static final EnumSet<CommandNames> userTaskCommand = EnumSet.of(
private static final EnumSet<CommandNames> systemCommand = EnumSet.of(CommandNames.BYE);
* Executes the expected behaviour of the class.
* @return The response string of the execution.
* @throws DukeException If some argument supplied to the command is invalid.
public abstract DukeResponse execute() throws DukeException;
* Static method that parses the input given by the user.
* It checks if the supplied input is valid or not, before determining which Command
* subclass object should be instantiated and returned. It also determines and validates
* the arguments supplied to the specific Command by the user. If any of the arguments
* are invalid, or required but not supplied, the object is not created and instead a DukeException will be thrown.
* @param input The entire string that was supplied by the user.
* @throws DukeException Thrown if arguments supplied are invalid.
String input, TaskList tasks, ClientList clients, TasksStorage tasksStorage) throws DukeException {
assert !input.isBlank() : "Input given should not be blank";
throw new DukeException("I don't know what " + specifiedCommand + " means.");
return new ByeCommand(); // TODO: Handle edge case where command is valid but doesn't belong anywhere.
* ByeCommand handles the user command "bye". The object should alert Duke that
* the program is being terminated by the user.
* Checks if the other object is a ByeCommand.
* @param other The other object to be checked against.
* @return True if the other object is a ByeCommand.
* SystemCommand class handles the commands which relate to the Duke chat-bot system, instead of the logical
* program execution. SystemCommands are commands such as 'Bye'.
public abstract class SystemCommand extends Command {
* @param command The command enum supplied by the user.
* DeadlineCommand handles the necessary arguments for the successful creation of a Deadline task object
* and appends it to the existing task list. It receives 2 mandatory arguments, description and
* deadlineDateTime, which are required in the creation of a Deadline task object.
* Creates a new DeadlineCommand with the necessary, validated arguments.
* @param description      The description of the Deadline task.
* @param deadlineDateTime The due-date for the Deadline task.
* Creates a new Deadline task object, and adds it to the current task list being maintained by Duke.
* Adds the task to the TasksStorage.
* @throws DukeException Thrown if Deadline object was unsuccessfully created.
* @return The response of the result of the execution.
throw new DukeException("Failed to create new deadline item: " + e.getMessage());
* DeleteCommand handles the deletion of the given task at the specified index. It contains the argument
* index, which is the index of the task that the user wants to delete.
* DeleteCommand will check if the target index exists before attempting to delete.
* Stores the necessary argument for the delete operation.
* @param index The index of the item that the user wants to delete.
* Deletes the task from the list of tasks given by Duke. If the index does not yet exist,
* execute will return an error, stating that the index does not exist.
* Removes the item from the list of saved items.
* @throws DukeException Thrown if the index does not exist, i.e. it exceeds the current size of the TaskList.
* @return The response of the result of the execution.
throw new DukeException("The task you are attempting to delete does not exist");
String responseMessage = "Alright! Getting rid of the following task: \n" + delTask + "\n";
* EventCommand handles the necessary arguments for the successful creation of an Event task object
* and appends it to the existing task list. It receives 2 mandatory arguments, description and
* eventDateTime, which are required in the creation of an Event task object.
* Creates a new EventCommand with the necessary, validated arguments.
* @param description   The description of the Event.
* @param eventDateTime The occurrence-date for the Event.
* Creates a new Event task object, and adds it to the current task list being maintained by Duke.
* Adds the task to the tasksStorage.
* @throws DukeException Thrown if Event object was unsuccessfully created.
* @return The response of the result of the execution.
throw new DukeException("Failed to create new event item: " + e.getMessage());
* FindCommand handles the necessary arguments for a filter operation on the TaskList, specifically a filter on the
* names of the TaskList items. It receives 2 mandatory arguments, description and
* eventDateTime, which are required in the creation of an Event task object.
* Stores the necessary argument for the search operation.
* @param search The search query that is to be matched against.
* Searches for and returns items which name matches the {@code search} parameter supplied by the user.
* @throws DukeException Thrown if the filter did not succeed.
* @return The response of the result of the execution.
lc.changeListMessage("Alright, here are your matching tasks: ");
* ListCommand handles outputting the entire list of tasks that a user has at the current point in time.
* It has an optional argument field dateFilter, which will filter the list of tasks to output
* based on whether they 1. have a dateTime field, and 2. the date of the field is equal to the specified
* dateFilter supplied by the user. Note: time is irrelevant here, and filter works solely based on date.
private String listMessage = "Alright, here are your tasks.";
* Creates a ListCommand object that has no specified dateFilter.
* Creates a ListCommand object that has some specified dateFilter.
* @param date The date that tasks should be filtered based on.
* Prints out all the tasks that the user has logged so far in a neat table format. Metadata (the total tasks)
* are printed out at the top of the table. If this object has some dateFilter, the tasks outputted
* will be filtered based on the dateFilter supplied.
* @throws DukeException Thrown if the filter did not succeed.
* @return The response of the result of the execution.
* MarkCommand handles the marking of some task as done. It receives a required argument, index, which is the
* index of the task that the user wishes to mark as done.
* Creates a MarkCommand object with the specified index argument.
* @param index The index of the task that the user wishes to mark as done.
* Marks the task from the list of tasks given by Duke as done. If the index does not yet exist,
* execute will return an error, stating that the index does not exist.
* @throws DukeException Thrown if the index does not exist, i.e. it exceeds the current size of the TaskList.
* @return The response of the result of the execution.
throw new DukeException("The task you are attempting to mark does not exist");
String responseMessage = "Good job! Let's keep it going, this spaceship needs you!\n" + task + "\n";
* ToDoCommand handles the necessary arguments for the successful creation of a ToDo task object
* and appends it to the existing task list. It receives 1 mandatory argument, description,
* which is required in the creation of a ToDo task object.
* Creates a new ToDoCommand with the necessary, validated argument.
* @param description The description of the ToDo task.
* Creates a new ToDo task object, and adds it to the current task list being maintained by Duke.
* Adds the item to the tasksStorage.
* @return The response of the result of the execution.
* UnmarkCommand handles the marking of some task as not done. It receives a required argument, index, which is the
* index of the task that the user wishes to mark as undone.
* Creates an UnmarkCommand object with the specified index argument.
* @param index The index of the task that the user wishes to mark as not done.
* Marks the task from the list of tasks given by Duke as undone. If the index does not yet exist,
* execute will return an error, stating that the index does not exist.
* @throws DukeException Thrown if the index does not exist, i.e. it exceeds the current size of the TaskList.
* @return The response of the result of the execution.
throw new DukeException("The task you are attempting to unmark does not exist");
String responseMessage = "I thought you were done with it?\n" + task + "\n";

* TaskList that Duke maintains, and the TasksStorage. It also handles the parsing of a given command to return a proper
public abstract class UserTaskCommand extends Command {
* Supplies to the UserTaskCommand the necessary fields for proper execution. This is necessary, since we want
* the Command class to handle the dissemination of necessary data to the correct Command subtype, i.e. this is
* to prevent Duke from having to handle the type of command it receives, and then to pass it the correct data
* @param tasksStorage The TasksStorage that Duke uses.
* @param tasks The tasks that Duke is maintaining.
public UserTaskCommand supply(Storage tasksStorage, TaskList tasks) {

* MainWindow is the window in which all Duke related GUI will exist and operate.
* Creates two dialog boxes, one echoing user input and the other containing Duke's reply and then appends them to
* the dialog container. Clears the user input after processing.
* A GUI for Duke using FXML.

* constructor also sets up the data structure containing the list of clients and attaches a listener between it
* TasksStorage is the class that handles all storage-related information and methods of the Duke chat-bot.
* A TasksStorage object encapsulates the necessary information for storing and restoring of the user's saved tasks.
* This includes the directory which is being used as the storage, and some Enums being used to parse
private static final String DATA_FILEPATH = DATA_DIRECTORY + "/duke.txt";
* Creates a new TasksStorage object which is able to save and restore tasks to a pre-defined location.
* TasksStorage attempts to create the necessary directories and files without explicitly checking if they
* already exist. Since creating existing directories and files only fails silently, there is no explicit checks
* @throws IOException Thrown if the creation/opening of the files and directories failed.
System.out.println("Creating a file directory for save file now: " + DATA_DIRECTORY);
System.out.println("Save file directory already exists: " + DATA_DIRECTORY);
System.out.println("Creating a save file now: " + DATA_FILEPATH);

* The TaskList class encapsulates the list of tasks that the chat-bot has to maintain, and which are saved from

return tasks.size() - 1; // Account for empty index 0

* The DukeResponse class encapsulates the data that might be returned by an execution of the Duke bot.
* The possible response statuses of a DukeResponse that is received from executing some command in Duke.
public enum ResponseStatus { SUCCESS, FAIL, EXIT }
* Creates an instance of the DukeResponse object.
* @param status The status of the execution.
* @param message The message associated with the execution and its status.
* Creates an instance of the DukeResponse object which has no message.

public void restore(TaskList emptyTasks) throws DukeException {
* The SaveFormatParser class is meant to extract the important client-facing information from the Duke toSaveFormat
* method return String. Specifically, it removes the saveId value from the String. This is important as:
* 1. A task's saveId is only important for identification during save-file updates that occur during the program
* 2. Ensuring that IDs are created in a consistent manner is unimportant.
* This is to ensure that we can test the important aspects of the save-string without affecting the test quality.
* Also, the id field itself is important, and is implicitly tested through the parsing.
